Title: Wabi-Sabi: for Artists, Designers, Poets & Philosophers
Author: Leonard Koren
My Review: Obsession with the perfect, the complete and the permanent is kind of a problem nowadays. A design needs to be complete, a person should be perfect, a product should be permanent. Wabi-sabi is a philosophy that embraces the opposite: Impermanence, imperfection, and incompleteness. Koren's book gave a short overview, but it's an interesting topic to delve deeper into.

Title: The Sailor Who Fell from Grace With the Sea
Author: Yukio Mishima
My Review:
I had to read some articles and explanations on the book, because the ending doesn't make sense.

Mishima was a nationalist who believed in Japanese purism or "national essence", and because he got radicalized, he attempted a coupe, but after that failed he committed suicide. This book is kind of a prediction of the coupe he wanted to do.

Title: A Little Life
Author: Hanya Yanagihara
My Review:
The cover is apparently a 1964 photo called "Orgasmic Man" for a person who no one really knows much about. Which fits the main character of the story. Nice.

The book is a view into severe childhood trauma, how a traumatic person thinks and views life, how his interactions with people around him happen, and probably how not to deal with a person who had severe trauma. The description of Jude's inner thoughts were very good and insightful. A Little Life is also probably one of the most stressful novels I've read. It has a lot of graphic scenes, but the interactions between the characters were sometimes very uncomfortable, in a realistic way. The chemistry between the characters was probably the main strengths of the book, and it was really interesting to see them grow up together and see how they changed and how their interactions evolved, positively and negatively.

Title: Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review: Hardest Murakami read so far, probably because of the random short story format. Men Without Women was also a short story collection, which I loved, but it had a theme to it and the stories felt more interesting. Here there are too many stories, there's no theme to them, you're jumping from one story to another, and it's hard to be invested before they're over. I think the quality of the stories also isn't as good as in Men Without Women.

My Review:
The advice here boils to the following: Be mindful and focused (nowadays the answer for that is meditation and journaling), be careful of what you're mentally consuming (everything you consume has an influence on you), listen to music to influence your mood, and stay physically healthy by eating healthy and doing sport.

There are some exercises that help reaching some of the advices, and specific ones for specific situations, so revisiting some sections might be helpful in the future.

Title: 1Q84 (1Q84 #1-3)
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review:
I read all of Murakami's novels before finishing this one, and 1Q84 felt like a test of some sorts. The story is pretty simple, and 1157 pages were definitely not necessary to tell it, but I think if you read and enjoy Murakami then you read his books for how he describes life. How he describes relationships, sceneries, emotions, how he utilizes metaphors and how he adds a fine touch of magical realism that generally doesn't lead anywhere, but makes you wonder what it metaphorically means (if it has any meaning), and makes a reread in the future interesting, because you would look at everything in a different light. And makes you appreciate the details and descriptions much more.

And according to goodreads, it took me exactly 6 months to finish the book. Interesting.

Title: Naturally Tan
Author: Tan France
My Review:
When things get a bit deep, he starts with a disclaimer, as if he's not comfortable talking about it or going into deeper subjects. Which is a shame. In some videos he also gets emotional when he talks about his childhood and his interactions with the Muslim community, so I understand why he doesn't want to talk about deeper subjects, but the book felt extremely superficial for the most part.

I would've liked a memoir about the struggles of a muslim gay south Asian fashion designer who now became popular, but this is not it.

Title: Embrace Your Weird: Face Your Fears and Unleash Creativity
Author: Felicia Day
My Review:
There's a lot of sound advice in here, and it will help many people. It's just filled with so much noise.

First of all the book is not about creativity, it's about self-help and understanding yourself. The author goes through a process that is similar to how some forms of therapy are conducted, focusing on problem solving issues like childhood trauma, dealing with different negative emotions, and how to build a healthy social life around you. It's just all dumbed down and filled with internet and gaming memes, monologues, and sections where the author wants you to write something. If I want to write I have a journal I write in, I bought a book to read it.

Many people will like the book, and if you dont mind books with a lot of 'energy' in them and you're struggling with emotional issues and not sure what to do, then go ahead and read the book.

If you're looking for anything about creative work or something more structured and to the point then look somewhere else. I would recommend Steven Pressfield for creativity or Brené Brown for self-development.

Title: Show Your Work!: 10 Ways to Share Your Creativity and Get Discovered
Author: Austin Kleon
My Review: Bit sized tips aimed to provide a push for creative people. You can always go much deeper into any of these subjects listed here, but it's a good way to read again when you're in need of a push. For me it's like a short aesthetically pleasing summary of things I delved deeper into elsewhere.

Title: Range: Why Generalists Triumph in a Specialized World
Author: David   Epstein
My Review:
"Don't feel behind". That's the point the book is trying to make. Follow your interests instead, don't follow a set path dictated by someone else or by society, and don't compare yourself to others. Interests arise from experimentation in life, and they're not set and can change with time. Follow them and delve into different areas. Delving into different fields or hobbies or careers, i.e. being a generalist, can have more benefits than sticking to one thing your whole life.

The book is a slog though. It's a Gladwell type of book, a book told through the eyes of an investigative journalist, where the author jumps from one story to another all the time, and depending on your knowledge, experiences and interests, some stories can feel extremely boring, while other stories can feel very interesting. There is a lot of insight, but it's buried somewhere in the book, or on the covers of it.

Title: Digital Minimalism
Author: Cal Newport

Author: Seth Stephens-Davidowitz

Title: Sophie's World: A Novel About the History of Philosophy
Author: Jostein Gaarder
My Review: This book is dense, and needs to be read slowly. While the young adult novel aspects were interesting, they dragged it a bit at some points. I think I cared more about the history, which was very enlightening, especially near the end. Something it did though is make me more interested in modern philosophy.

Title: Hope and Help for Your Nerves
Author: Claire Weekes
My Review: This book and its content are outdated. It's a feel-good book with no real practical advice that supports the author's promise of this book "definitely 100% helping you". And the book has very outdated language. There are better  terms in psychology that defines what the author cant define but threw under the term "nervousness". Different people have different types of "nervousness", or what's nowadays called "disorders", and to heal different disorders you need to be able to define what they are first, and then try to understand how they came to be. This book might have helped many when it came out, but there are much better modern alternatives that try to talk about modern issues.
